description: A hearty, wholesome, and nutritious one-pot stew of slow-cooked beans and maize (dried corn kernels), creating a complete protein and a foundational dish in Ugandan cuisine.

cultural_significance.cultural_notes: Kande is the ultimate comfort food for many Ugandans. It is affordable, filling, and highly nutritious. It's a common dish in homes, school feeding programs, and at roadside food stalls. The combination of beans and maize provides a complete protein, making it a vital part of the local diet.

ingredients.name: Dried Beans
ingredients.notes: Red kidney beans or any local variety, soaked overnight

steps.instruction: Drain the beans and maize that were soaked overnight. Rinse them thoroughly under cold running water.
In a large, heavy pot, combine the rinsed beans and maize. Add 6 cups of water.

Bring to a boil over high heat. Then reduce the heat to low, cover the pot, and let it simmer for 60-90 minutes, or until both the beans and maize are tender. Skim off any foam that forms on the surface.

cooking_indicators.visual: The beans will split open slightly, and the maize will puff up and become soft.
cooking_indicators.texture: Both beans and maize should be soft enough to eat easily.

steps.instruction: While the beans and maize are cooking, heat the vegetable oil in a separate pan over medium heat. Sauté the chopped onions until soft and translucent.
Add the minced garlic and grated ginger (if using). Sauté for another 2 minutes until fragrant.
Stir in the curry powder and cook for 30 seconds.
Add the chopped tomatoes and cook for 5-7 minutes, mashing them with the spoon until they form a thick paste.
Once the beans and maize are tender, pour this cooked tomato and onion mixture (the 'mchuzi') into the large pot with them. Add salt and stir everything together thoroughly.

Let the combined stew simmer uncovered for another 15-20 minutes over low heat. This allows the flavors to meld and the stew to thicken to your desired consistency. Stir occasionally to prevent sticking.

cooking_indicators.visual: The stew will thicken and the colors will blend together.
cooking_indicators.texture: Creamy and thick, with tender beans and maize.

steps.instruction: Taste and adjust the salt if needed. Serve hot.
Serve the Kande hot in a bowl.

serving_suggestions: Traditionally served on its own as a complete meal. Can also be accompanied by a slice of avocado, a side of leafy greens like Sukuma Wiki, or with Chapati or Ugali for a more filling meal.
